div.p: 1. V:30. Friday. The breeze continued through the Night, and with some diminution all this day. Before Midnight last Evening the Captain perceived by a peculiar smell which was also perceptible to the passengers who went upon the deck that the ship had come upon soundings. I found upon going on deck this Morning a striking change in the feeling of the Atmosphere, and in the temperature of the Water since yesterday Morning. Air 58. Water 59. undoubted proof that we are no longer in the meshes of the gulph stream. The colour of the Water had also changed from a deep and limpid blue to a yellowish and turbid green. Latitude at Noon 41:51. Reckoning Longitude 72:25. but as that would put us high and dry upon the land, we are compelled to take a step backwards, and the Captain now estimates the real Longitude at 68. But as he was unwilling to lose the benefit of the breeze by laying to, he postponed sounding until the Night. The weather was cool and pleasant, with so little motion of the ship, that I employed all the morning in writing and reading— By which means however I missed seeing a Shark, several dog-fish, a turtle and a sword fish, all of which were seen by the passengers upon deck— I was busied, making out an account of Books, purchased for the War Department, and reading de Augmentis Scientiarum. The Cabin loo-table was at work, morning, afternoon and Evening. After dinner I played three games of Chess, successfully with Mr Otis. I give him a Castle and beat him, when I can command my attention, but that is not always in my power. The Evening till ten I passed upon deck Star-gazing. The sky was perfectly clear, and I recognized all the principal Constellations that were above the horizon. The whole Scorpion was in full sight, with Jupiter who has been our steady companion upon the larboard Quarter, the voyage through. There was one Star which rose between eight and nine in Aquarius, and which after some doubt I ascertained to be the planet Saturn.

2. IV:45. At two O’clock this morning the Captain sounded and found bottom at 50. fathoms; he supposes on St. George’s Bank. The air was at 62. Water 60. Weather all day fine with an easterly breeze so light that it was little better than calm; yet carrying the ship from two to three knots an hour. We saw at a distance, two fore-top-sail Schooners; probably coasting vessels— I read De Augmentis Scientiarum, and wrote very little. Afternoon at Chess with Mr Otis: Evening upon deck Star-gazing; until the Moon rose, about half past ten, under the square of Pegasus, and directly astern of the ship Latitude 41:17. Longitude, estimated at 69:30. The Cabin Card Table has no other intervals from breakfast to Midnight, than for dinner and supper— Several Sculls of Porpoises were seen, and perhaps a turtle and a sword fish.— There was a premature cry of Land, by one of the Sailor’s this Morning.

3. IV: My wife was very sick, about day-break this morning which occasioned my rising so early. When I went upon deck it was the Morning twilight, but Venus was shining in all her splendour. Mars was also visible, and the principal stars of several Constellations. Orion was not entirely risen, but his upper part and belt were plainly seen; as were the Pleiades, Aldebaran, and the Bulls horns.— Mr Fearon was called up, to see the Sunrise, which he did, not altogether clear. But we watched the disappearance of Venus, to remark how long she could abide the Solar light before she would hide her diminished head. I saw her till ten minutes after the whole disk of the Sun was above the horizon, when she vanished from my sight— Mr Fearon, and the man of the Helm, Williams saw her fifteen minutes longer. The Air was at 67. Water at 68. The weather was very fine, but the Sun hot, and all the morning, a bare breath of Easterly wind, carried from one knot to one and a half in an hour. After noon it freshened to a four and five knot breeze. Latitude 40:14 Longitude, corrected 70:25. After dinner, about 5 O’Clock we met and spoke the Brig Alliance, Patten, of Kennebunk, bound to that place, from Port au Prince, out 17 days. Her Longitude at Noon this day 71:20. Had soundings three days ago; her Captain supposed, West of Nantucket Shoals. Several sculls of porpoises were seen.— I could not write, and from drowsiness read with much difficulty: some pages of Hewlett’s Commentary on the Bible; and two of Chalmers’s Astronomical Sermons. The Evening was warm and cloudy—wind drawing gradually ahead— I left them at ten, making social verses in the Cabin— I took a glass of the Sea water this morning, and found it scarcely salt.

4. IV: Rose again at this early hour; but the sky was overcast and neither Stars nor Sunrise to be seen. There were a brig keeping the same course with us, and two top-sail Schooners in sight. Air 72. Water 71. Soon after eleven O’Clock the land was seen, by a Sailor named Robertson, and Mr Coit the Mate; and about Noon by several of the Passengers from the deck. It was one before I could discern it even through the Spy-glass. The Latitude by observation at Noon was 40:26., within two miles of that of New-York. the corrected Longitude 72:56. which must be very near right— We kept our course westward until within five or six Miles of the Land which was the Northern shore of Long-Island, when the wind being at S.W. blowing almost a gale, they were obliged at seven this Evening to put the ship about and stand from the lee-shore.— The brig was three or four miles to windward of us, and kept her course towards the land until we lost sight of her in the dark. Mr Coit thought that the land first seen was Montauk point, the Eastern extremity of Long-island, and that the land towards which we approached nearest was Blue-point; about 35 Miles from Sandy Hook. The Evening was clear; but blowing too fresh and with too much tossing of the ship to be pleasant. There was also, and has been for several Evenings past so heavy a fall of dew that the deck is wet with it as after a washing.— Writing has become so very irksome to me that I now barely continue my journal from day to day— I finished reading the first Volume of De Augmentis Scientiarum. Passed the afternoon with Dr. Tillary and Mr Otis at Chess— Soon after nine I left the Cabin Passengers at the Loo-table. Before Midnight there was a sharp Squall, and change of wind to N.W.

5. V:45. From the terror of the lee shore the Captain stood out to Sea till four O’clock this Morning; and the wind being nearly at West all the early part of this day, we were beating against it with a course S.S.W. till about Noon the Land was made again. This time it was the Highlands of Neversink: but the wind was still ahead; and after approaching the land till six in the Evening we stood off again two hours. The stiff breeze having lulled
to a moderate pitch, at eight we stood again towards the land, and immediately after the Light at Sandy Hook was seen from the tops. Before ten I saw it revolve, from the deck— The air this morning was at 70, and the water at 71. Latitude at Noon 40:15. Longitude 73:20. There were several vessels in sight, large and small the whole day. I read Bacon in the Morning, and played Chess with Dr Tillary and Mr Otis after dinner.

6. IV: New-York— I rose immediately after day-light this Morning. The ship was within three miles of the highlands of Neversink, and the new Sandy Hook Lighthouse in full sight, as well as the two old ones; all the lights were still burning. The morning was fine, and almost all the passengers soon came upon deck. The Sun rose clear, and Venus was visible more than a quarter of an hour after he had risen— Air and Water both at 67. There were a number of vessels in sight and among the rest a Pilot-Boat Schooner from which a Pilot, named Bird, came on board at six. we had a fair and light breeze, which took us up to the wharf at New-York, where we landed at one in the afternoon immediately from the Ship. Several persons from the Custom-House came on board just before we reached the City; but they had been preceded by persons from the Newspaper Printing-Offices, who came for news. I gave Lang the Copy of the British Treasury Order which I had received from the Collector at Cowes. The approach to New-York, was slow, and the termination of the Voyage as agreeable as could be wished— The Sentiments with which after an absence of eight full and eventful years I touched once more, my native Land were of a mingled nature— Of the deepest gratitude to the Supreme disposer, for all the enjoyments and preservations of that long period, and particularly for the safe and happy close of the voyage just completed; together with an anxious forecast of the cares and perils of the new Scene upon which I am about to enter. The latter of these feelings was greater and more oppressive than it had ever been on returning to my Country heretofore. So keen indeed was the emotion of contemplating the probabilities of the future time that nothing but a firm reliance upon him who has ever been my preserver and the dispenser of every blessing, supported me from despondency. We left Antoine on board the ship to take care of our baggage and effects, for the delivery of which an Order from the Collector of the Customs will be necessary. On stepping from the wharf we met Mr Saltus whom we had known at St. Petersburg, and shortly after Mr Moses— We took lodgings at Mrs Bradish’s, on the Battery, where we found as fellow lodgers Captain Biddle of our Navy, Commodores Rogers and Decatur, Mr Graham, late chief Clerk in the Department of State, Mr John R. Livingston, and his Son, Montgomery Livingston who was last year in London; and several others. Captain Warrington of the Navy, with his Lady came in while we were at dinner, just arrived in three days from Norfolk. Immediately after dinner Mr Slade, whom we knew at St. Petersburg came in— He is also a lodger at this house. Early in the Evening he walked out with us, and I deposited many letters at the Post-Office. In Broadway we were overtaken by Mr Edward Coles just arrived from Liverpool, which he sailed from 21. June. He gave me some despatches from J. A. Smith, and among them a letter of 17—June; with some additional papers from Mr Bentham. In the Evening I had some conversation with Mr Graham, who has resigned his situation as Chief Clerk in the Department of State, and is now going with Mr Rodney to South America on a special mission concerning which he is to speak further with me to-morrow.

7. V:30. Immediately after breakfast, Mr Graham shewed me the Instructions from the Department of State, to Mr Rodney and him, for their Mission to South-America, concerning which I had some further conversation with him— At ten I went to the Custom-House, and received from Mr Gelston the Collector an order for the delivery of all my baggage from the ship— I met in Broadway, Dr Cooke the Clergyman belonging to our Navy who lately returned from England; who had a long story of excuse and apology to tell me, about the failure of his friend and agent here, upon whom he gave me a bill to repay the money which I lent him last Summer, in London; which bill has never been paid. The Doctor talked of drawing upon Mr Frend, and of his pay as a Navy Chaplain; and promised to call upon me to-morrow Morning. I went to Mr M’Cormick’s house, but found he was out of town upon a tour to Canada. At the Bank of America, I
found W. S. Clarkson, who was then engaged there, but called upon us towards Evening. We had a continual succession of visitors the whole day and Evening; scarcely allowing an interval for dinner, and principally of persons with whom we were unacquainted. In the Evening Mr Astor, Mr Colden, & Mrcame as a Committee from a meeting of Gentlemen, and invited me to a public dinner, asking me to fix the day. I accepted the invitation for next Monday. Sir James L. Yeo arrived here last Evening with the British Frigate Inconstant which he commands. He comes from Jamaica and the Havanna, with nearly half a Million of Dollars, for the Bank of the United States. His ship being put under a Quarantine of thirty days, he determined to sail immediately for England. He sent me his Compliments with an offer to take Letters. I therefore wrote to J. A. Smith, and gave him the Letter this Evening. Among our visitors in the course of the day, were Coll and Mrs Trumbull, Mr Astor, Mr A. Gracie, Mr Gelston, Genl. Morton, Coll. Talmadge, Mr Leavenworth, Mr Riker, Miss Ramsay, (whom I had seen in the year 1784 and not since) and who came with her nephew young Mr M’Comb, with many others.

8. VI:30. Captain Hughes, Master of the Sloop Margaret, bound to Washington, brought me a Letter from Mr Gelston the Collector, recommending him for the Carriage of our baggage and furniture to that place. I accordingly made the agreement with him that he should take it, and he promised to draw immediately his Sloop along-side of the Ship Washington at the Old Slip, and to have our effects at once passed from one Vessel to the other. Antoine went with him to see that it should be done with proper care and attention— I wrote a Letter to Mr Richard Rush now the acting Secretary of State; but from the multitude of interruptions was too late to send it by the Post. The succession of visitors continued until dinner time. Among them were the Vice-President Mr Tompkins, Mr Buchanan the British and Mr Gahn the Swedish Consuls— Mr and Mrs Gracie and their daughter with Mr Charles King. His brother James had been here yesterday. Mr and Mrs Gracie invited us, all the family, to dine with them to-morrow. Mrs Bentzon and her sister Miss Astor were of the visitors— Mr Lawrence, formerly Secretary of the Mission to Sweden, and whom I had seen with Mr Russell at Stockholm—and a Mr Johnson, appointed Consul at Calais, and who was introduced to me by Mr Graham. Mr and Mrs De Wint, (my Sister’s daughter Caroline) came from their residence on Hudson’s river in Duchess County, 65 miles from the City to see us— After dinner I went with George, and saw them at their lodgings N. 53. Day Street, at Mrs Moore’s. We met there W. S. Clarkson; and a young man named Dashwood, who in June 1814. was a fellow passenger with me in the John Adams from Gothenburg to the Texel.— I called at the Post-Office to deliver sundry packets and Letters, but found it shut up— I found it too warm for walking and returned to our lodgings at Mrs Bradish’s for the Evening. Commodore Rogers and Decatur, are to leave town to-morrow Morning for Washington, and took charge of Packets for Mr and Mrs Caton at Baltimore, and for Mr Bagot. I had much Conversation in the Evening with Mr Graham; upon the state of our public foreign relations, and the Department of State.— I find the warmth of the weather exceedingly oppressive; having experienced nothing like it since I left Boston in 1809.

9. VII: There were few visitors this Morning; and among them a son of Mr Gracie’s. Mr Hurd, whom I had left at St. Petersburg in 1814. a young man, named Robertson, who told me that he had an appointment as commercial agent at Lima, from the Department of State, and was waiting here to obtain the means of conveyance to his destination. He had applied to Captain Biddle for a passage in the Ontario, the Sloop of War in which the Commissioners, Graham and Rodney are going out; but he feared he should not obtain it for want of room. Mr Emlyn of Philadelphia, whom I had seen at Ghent was also here. I paid visits to the British Consul Mr Buchanan, who received me at his Office, and to Mr Gahn, Swedish Consul, but he was not at home. I was at Genl: Morton’s, also without finding him at home. We visited at Mr Trumbull’s, where we saw his pictures and a bust of him, taken by a young Roman Sculptor, who is here soliciting employment— At Mr Astor’s we found nobody at home.— We all went out, with Mr Edward Coles and dined at Mr Gracie’s seat at Hell-Gate, or as they have lately taken a fashion of calling it Hurl-gate. It was a family party. Charles and James King were there with their wives, both of whom are Mr Gracie’s daughters. It was about nine in the Evening
when we came home. Mr Rufus King, and Judge B Livingston had called to see us this Morning while we were out.

10. VI: After a very heavy gale of wind yesterday, the weather this day was fine and clear, but the heat of the Sun is more insupportable to me than I had ever found it before. We all went this Morning to the Presbyterian Church in Wall-Street and heard Mr Whelply preach, from Psalm 137:5.6: [“]If I forget thee Oh Jerusalem, let my right hand forget her cunning. If I do not remember thee, let my tongue cleave to the roof of my Mouth; if I prefer not Jerusalem above my chief joy.” Mr and Mrs De Wint, and Clarkson went with us. After Church we went and looked at the magnificent Steam Boat, Chancellor Livingston, which arrived this morning from Albany. It is a travelling City.— We had visits from Mr and Mrs MaComb and their daughter Mr Middleton of South Carolina, and Mr Knox, a kinsman of the President’s. Mr Graham consulted me for advice, whether it would not be advisable to despatch the Sloop of War Ontario upon the South American expedition, with Mr Prevost, and Mr Breckenridge, merely to obtain information, and without either of the Commissioners— Mr Rodney’s son is so ill of the Nausichia, or home-sickness, accompanied with a raving delirium, that he is compelled to take him home to Wilmington, and knows not whether even then he himself can come back to proceed upon the expedition. The President meant that the Commission should consist of three persons, and would certainly not be satisfied if only one should go: and if time should now be taken to consult and obtain an answer from him, it would be too late to procure the information, which was one object of the expedition before the opening of the Session of Congress. I advised nevertheless to write again to Mr Rush for Instructions.— George dined with Clarkson, and went to hear Dr. Romaine after dinner. Towards Evening I took Mr Shiel with me to Mr Trumbull’s and introduced him, at his request. Cook and Clarkson and the boys went with us. Returning home we stopp’d at the City Hotel, and paid a visit to Mr and Mrs Lamb— John lost his dog this day.

11. V: Mr and Mrs De Wint came this morning. I went with him to Fulton Street, to enquire about the Steam Boats that go to New-Haven— There was one went off this Morning; the next is to go at seven O’Clock Wednesday Morning. Returning home I stopp’d at the U. S. Branch Bank, in Broadway, and exchanged some 20 franc pieces for Bills. Met Trumbull there, who promised to call upon me at one O’Clock and shew me the Academy of Arts; but a violent storm of wind and rain came up, so that he did not call— There were several visitors, among whom Mr Gibson, whom we knew at St. Petersburg. Frederick Tudor was here. He comes with his Mother from Bordentown where she has been to spend some time with her daughter Mrs Stewart. I received a Letter from Vice-President Tompkins apologising for not attending at the dinner this day.— Mr Graham also had some scruple at the suggestion of his colleague Mr Rodney, that his appearance there might give too much publicity to their Mission. He finally concluded however to go. I also received a Letter from H. J. Knox, son of the late General Knox, dated at the Debtors Prison where he is confined, and soliciting relief. De Wint and his wife, are to return home by the Steam-Boat, to-morrow Morning. He gave me a check on a Bank for which I am to account with him— At four O’Clock, Mr Astor and Genl. Morris, Marshal of the District, came from the Committee of Arrangements and I went with them to the Public Dinner at Tammany Hall. There were about one hundred persons present, most of whom were introduced to me— Among them Governor De Witt Clinton. He told me that Mr Rush had written to him for information relative to weights and measures in this State; and he would send me a work of Olinthus Gregory upon the general subject. The person presiding at the dinner was General Clarkson. The Mayor, Mr Ratcliff invited me to dine with him and the City Corporation to-morrow at Bellevue, six miles out of the City. I came home about nine in the Evening.

12. VI:30. There was a gale of wind extremely violent, with torrents of rain, the whole Night; this morning, the storm abated, but the rain continued and kept me confined to the house. Between two and three O’Clock, the Mayor, Mr Ratcliff, came, and I went with him to Bellevue, where the members of the City Corporation
were assembled, at a quarterly visitation of the penitentiary and poor house. We stopp’d at the City Hall, where I left a Card for the Governor and the Books sent by Mr Bentham and Mr Owen— The Company at dinner were about forty persons, all members of the Corporation, but Mr E. Coles and my Son George whom the mayor had invited with me— Before dinner we saw the Steam-Boat from New-Haven passing up to New-York. After dinner we took a transient view of the penitentiary and its inhabitants— The poor house is a separate establishment— The Mayor complains of the great numbers of poor, that burthen the City—amounting at this Season to fifteen hundred and in winter to near two thousand. Two thirds of them foreigners. We returned about dusk to the City, and at the City Hall, I left Mr Ratcliff— Mr Lamb paid us an Evening visit. John’s dog was brought back.

13. VI: At the invitation of Captain Warrington we went with him and his Lady, Mr and Mrs Coles, Mr and Miss Skipwith, and Mr Edward Coles to the Navy Yard, upon Long-Island, where we saw the Steam Frigate— The Commander of the place is Captain Evans, who is now absent; engaged in the Survey of the Coast— We were received by the next Officer, Captain Renshaw, and met there Captain Trenchard of the Navy.— Upon enquiry I found that he had received very lately my Letter from England with the enclosure from Mr Hippisley. Mr Renshaw shewed us some American Canvas for the supply of the Navy; better and cheaper than English and Russian of the same number. The John Adams is lying at the Navy-Yard, and the Cyane which was taken by the Constitution— On returning from the Navy-Yard, I received Letters from my father and mother, written last Sunday: my Mother had received my Letter from this place. After dinner I sat to Mr Shiel, for my picture at his desire— Mr L. Harris was here in the Evening arrived from a visit to Mr J. Allen Smith who resides in New-Jersey. The heat continues excessive.

14. VII: I sat twice to Mr Shiel; two hours each time; this morning and after dinner; and promised him one more sitting when I return to New-York. Called on Mr Trumbull—and found him with the frame for his large picture of the Declaration of Independence; upon which he is just preparing to begin. He accompanied me, with my Sons John and Charles, first to the City Hall, where I visited Governor Clinton and afterwards to the Academy of Arts, the Historical Society, the Cabinet of Natural History and the Museum. On returning I met Judge B. Livingston in Broadway.— Went with my wife on board the Ship Washington at the Old Slip; and took our final leave of her. I settled with Captain Forman for the freight of our baggage and effects in the Ship Washington from London to New-York. Left them transshipping to the Sloop Margaret Captain Hughes for Washington.— After sitting to Shiel, till dusk I went to the wharf at the end of Fulton Street; to enquire for a passage in the Steam-boat Connecticut for New-Haven. They told me that it was needless to engage a passage; and only necessary to be on board at seven in the Morning. At which time on Mondays Wednesdays and Fridays the Connecticut leaves the wharf. She arrives at New-Haven at five or six in the afternoon on the same days. The Fulton Steam Boat is at same time going from New-London to New-Haven. The Passengers, pass from one boat to the other. The Fulton immediately departs for New-London, where she arrives the next Morning at five or six. A Line of Stages is in attendance at New London to take the passengers immediately through Providence on to Boston, where they arrive before midnight the same day, making a complete passage from New-York to Boston in forty hours.— There were several visitors this morning while I was abroad; and among them L. Harris, who came again in the Evening. W. S. Clarkson was also here, and furnished me the bills necessary to accomplish our homeward journey.

15. IV: By some negligence of mine, which I should think inexcusable in another, I mistook the hour of the morning as indicated by my watch, and after rising thus early, instead of rousing the rest of the family, and packing up with all possible expedition, I sat down to write at this Journal, and continued thus employed till the boys came knocking at the door and announcing that it was close upon seven O’Clock. We then made what despatch we could but the Clock struck seven before we left Mrs Bradish’s house, and just as we came to Fulton Street Captain Forman met us and informed us that the Steam-Boat had been about five minutes gone— For the next opportunity by the Steam Boat we must have waited until Monday. I therefore went immediately to Crane-wharf and found the Packet Fame, Captain Gardiner, bound to Newport and Providence, and prepared to sail at five
O’Clock this afternoon— I engaged our passage on board this vessel, and we returned to Breakfast at Mrs Bradish’s. Mr and Mrs Coles and Miss Skipwith had gone off at seven, in the Steam-Boat for Albany. Mr Cook was to have gone at ten, on that for Amboy, but like us was too late. I sat a couple of hours to Shiel, who still asks for another sitting on our return. While I was there Captain Forman came in with De Wint’s check which they had refused to take at the Bank. I went with it to Clarkson, who took it immediately to the Bank, and procured the money. I called again at the Ship Washington, but Captain Forman not being there I left the money with Antoine to be paid to him. We dined at two; and Cook who dined with us went off at three. Mr Henry Wykoff of Philadelphia, who is making a tour came to the house, about an hour before we left it.— We embarked about four in the afternoon at Crane wharf with a fair wind, and a fresh breeze, which scarcely lasted us till we reached Hell-gate.— We passed through this passage with a calm; and reached the entrance of the Sound at Sands’s point about nine in the Evening. The heat of the Sun was almost insupportable.

16. IV: The Night was nearly calm, and it was six this Morning before we came abreast of New-Haven. The day was pleasant and cool, but with an easterly wind, very light and unfavourable to our progress. We did however Coast along the shore of Long-Island, with slow advances till at Sunset we passed out from the sound opposite to New-London and Gull-Island— We left Antoine and Mary Newell, at New-York to proceed with our baggage to Washington. My wife, my three Sons, and Lucy Hauel are with me— We have three other Ladies, and three men, passengers with us, but they form no Society for us— I read part of a Volume of Lord Bacon, de Augmentis Scientiarum, and wasted in most painful idleness, all the remainder of the day— I played Back-gammon and chess with the boys, and escaped as well as I could from my reflections.

17. IV:30. Towards the close of last Evening, it fell again totally calm, and the tide having turned against us we were drifting astern towards certain rocks at the eastern end of Fisher’s Island. The vessel was therefore brought to anchor in sight of the Watch-Hill Light-House near Stonington. Just before I rose they had weighed anchor again; but the calm continued, and when a very gentle breeze sprung up it was nearly ahead. As the day advanced however it became more favourable, and freshened so that about eleven O’Clock we doubled the Cape at Point Judith; the Swell of the Sea, from the time we had left the Sound was as usual great and uncomfortable. We reached Newport just after noon, and without anchoring or touching at the wharf, landed one Passenger, and took on board another. We had now a fresh and favourable breeze, which landed us between four and five in the afternoon at Providence. I bespoke immediately an extra Stage, which took us up with our baggage at the wharf; and after stopping five minutes at the door of Chappotin’s Tavern, upon the Hill, the house formerly kept by Ammidown, we came on to what is called the half-way house kept by Fuller, at Walpole— Chappotin an old acquaintance of mine, a frenchman, came to his door and spoke to me, before we left Providence— Between nine and ten we reached Walpole, where we found a very good lodging for the Night.

18. V: Quincy. I had engaged the Stage to come directly to this place, without going into Boston. We left Walpole at seven O’Clock, and after stopping at Dedham to change horses, arrived here between ten and eleven, and had the inexpressible happiness of finding my dear and venerable father and mother in perfect health. Louisa Smith is with them, and her Sister Mrs James H. Foster, with her son are here upon a visit— Within half an hour after our arrival my uncle Peter B. Adams my father’s brother came in to see me— My Son John immediately went to my brother’s house and he came with his wife to dinner— The heat of the day was as great as at any time since we landed at New-York.— My brother’s Children all came after dinner— They are five—Elizabeth, Abigail, Thomas B, Isaac Hull, and John Quincy— Mr T. Greenleaf junr. called to see us— In the Evening Mr Barney Smith came with his Son in Law, our late fellow passenger Mr G. A. Otis.— Mr Marston likewise an inhabitant of Quincy paid us an Evening visit.— Charles’s birthday. 10 years old— George 5 f 7 1/2 i. John 4. f 9 1/2 i. Charles 4. f 4 i.

19. V: My Mother and my wife went this morning with George to Mr Colman’s at Hingham, to enquire if he would take my Sons to prepare them for entering at Harvard University— Mr Colman had objections to taking either of them and no definitive arrangement was made. Mr Colman, Mr Kimball, and Mr Norton will come to Quincy next Saturday, and by an examination of George’s qualifications ascertain if he can enter the present year, whether as Sophomore or Freshman— There were a continual succession of visitors here the whole day. Mr Whitney with his Son—General Humphreys who engaged us to dine with him on Thursday. Captain Berk and his Son—Mrs Barney Smith, and Mrs G. A. Otis with Mr and Mrs Russell—W. S. Shaw who came out from Boston and dined here. He brought me a Letter from R. Rush of the 14th. in answer to mine from New-York to him and cards of invitation to Commencement from President Kirkland to me, and from Mr & Mrs T. L. Winthrop to my wife and me. My brother had already brought us a similar invitation from Mr Henry Warren of Plymouth. Immediately after dinner Commodore Hull came, with Edward Wyer, who is going as Consul to Hamburg, then Joseph Hall; soon followed by W. Gray, Arnold Welles, and G. Blake, who came to invite me from Citizens of Boston to a public dinner next Friday. They also invited my father, my brother and my Son George— He went to Boston with Shaw.— I went with my Father to Mr Quincy’s, but he was gone to Andover.— We found however Mrs Quincy, and her daughters, five. Her mother Mrs Morton, Mr Isaac Davis and his wife were there from Boston— Upon our return to my father’s we found there Mr and Mrs T. Greenleaf, Mr and Mrs John Greenleaf, Mrs Black, R. G. Shaw Mr G. Apthorp, with Mr Lindsay, and Mr De Grand. All these persons except Mr B. Smith’s family are my ancient friends and acquaintance— Mr and Mrs Russell are to sail to-morrow for Amsterdam, and E. Wyer is to go in the same vessel— Russell and Wyer have long been at variance, with each other and are by no means reconciled. Mr Russell returns to his Mission at Stockholm, to make some arrangement with regard to the Treaty which he negotiated there. It was ratified by the Senate with the exception of three Articles, which Russell shewed me. He says the objection to them was taken by Mr King in Senate from personal motives of animosity against him; because he had officially reported some observations made by Lord Castlereagh to him, in which he said Mr King had been mistaken, in supposing that the British Government had ever intended to give up the practice of impressing Seamen from American vessels.— He has not received his instructions, and knows not precisely what to say, to justify the exclusion of the excepted Articles. He thinks Bernadotte will be irritable about it; and he has concluded to go back to Stockholm which he detested, to shew that he has not lost the confidence of the American Government.— But he said he had told Mr Monroe, that if he was to continue in the Public Service at all he thought himself entitled to a better Mission than that of Sweden. He suggested that he should like that of Russia. He also shewed me his Letter of credit upon the Willink’s at Amsterdam and thought it objectionable because it was limited; but I informed him it was the usual practice. He had written to ask leave to go and wait for his Instructions at Paris. He shewed me Mr Rush’s answer; which was that he would write him again on the subject shortly.— Having engaged his passage and being bound to sail to-morrow, he cannot wait for this promised Letter, and asked me, if I saw any objection to his going to Paris— Under all the circumstances, I had none to make.— He begged of me to acknowledge the receipt of his Letters, which I promised to endeavour to do. He is disgusted with Wyer’s appointment, and vexed that he is going out in the same Ship with him— Wyer himself made me excuses and apologies, and professions of repentance for his Letters from Gothenburg. I told him I had long since given over all resentment for every thing personally offensive to myself in them; but recommended to him to provide for the payment of his debts in England. He promised he would, and said he had made money in Russia, and should have made his fortune there; but for the villainy of Venning with whom he had been in partnership.— I see no essential change in his character.

20. V:30. The visitors were, this morning, Mr William Foster, and his Sister Charlotte, and this afternoon A. H. Everett and his wife; and this Evening Mr Quincy who returned from his tour to Andover— Everett from the Committee for the public dinner, proposed to postpone the day till next Tuesday to which I agreed— I spent the afternoon with my wife, Mrs Foster and my Sons John and Charles at my brother’s. This Evening I was unwell, with a dull head-ache.

21. V:15. Boston. This morning I wrote Letters to the President of the United States, and to R. Rush. We concluded to commence our Journey on the sixth of next Month; and I informed Mr Rush that he may expect us at
Washington the 21st. of September. We had visits from Captain Bernard & Russell Sturgis, and from Mrs G. Apthorp and Miss Apthorp.— I came with my wife, Mrs Foster and Lucy to Boston. I had authorised W. S. Shaw to engage lodgings for us, at Mrs Jones’s in Pearl-Street, where he himself boards, but Mrs Foster so strongly urged us to go for this time to her house that we consented— We called for my brother and his wife at Mr Foster’s, and we dined with General Humphreys, where we met Dr Kirkland the President of the University at Cambridge, and Mr Artiguenave a French ci-devant actor of the French Theatre to whom I gave a Passport in London last year— After dinner we called to see Mrs S. A. Otis, where we met Dr Welsh and his daughter Harriet— Mr and Mrs Torrey, a daughter of Henry Warren, and his son Winslow. My brother and his wife returned this Evening to Quincy. We stay to lodge at Mr James H. Foster’s— Dr Welsh and Harriet, and Mr Jos. Hall and his wife were there. Mr and Mrs Cruft were at Mr Foster’s waiting for us, when we arrived there before dinner— Mrs Cruft is a daughter of my deceased friend and kinsman W. Smith.

22. V:30. This morning I took a walk with Mr Foster round the town, and witnessed with delight its great increase and improvements during the eight years of my absence from it— The central wharf, New Cornhill, and Common Street are three great masses of buildings erected within that time; and there are so many others of less extent, but contributing equally to the elegance and comfort of the place, that they compose scarcely less than half the town. The only alteration which I perceived with regret was the demolition of Beacon-Hill.— We returned to Breakfast at Mr Foster’s immediately after which we received visits from several of our friends—Messrs: Jonathan Mason, Isaac Smith, John Davis, Isaac Parker, Samuel Parkman and Benjamin Welles, and T. Welsh junr. and Mrs W. Gray called upon us. We accompanied W. S. Shaw to the Athenaeum; Mrs Gray, her Son Francis, and several other of the Gentlemen walked there with us. We met there Mrs S. A. Otis and her daughters. Coll: John T. Apthorp, Mr John Welles and General Humphreys. Shaw introduced to me Mr Gadsden of South-Carolina, a Grandson of the great revolutionary character of that name— I went with Jos. Hall to the State-House, and paid a visit to Governor Brooks. Hall intimated that the Committee for arranging the toasts had some thoughts of toasting me by name at the public dinner, with the expectation of my answering the toast by a speech according to the English fashion. I intreated him however to dissuade them from it—disapproving as I do the practice itself, and feeling the danger and inconvenience and impropriety there would be in speech making at public dinners for a person in the Station that I am to assume. Hall was fully satisfied with the reasons I gave, and promised to take care that the arrangements should be made accordingly. We returned to the Athenaeum where I met Mr John Phillips. I went with my wife to Mr Gardner Green’s, but neither he nor his wife was at home. We left the Letter from Mrs: Green’s mother Mrs Copley and returned to Mr James Foster’s. We met Mr W. Foster senior on the way; he had been to call upon us. I had received from him yesterday a written invitation to lodge at his house with my wife during our stay in Boston— Mrs Gray this morning gave us verbally this morning a similar invitation. I declined both as I had done that of Mr and Mrs James Foster, wishing to avoid being troublesome to any of our friends, though grateful to their kindness.— We came out with Harriet Welsh to dinner at my father’s at Quincy. After dinner we had visits from Mr and Mrs H. G. Otis, and Shaw came out with Mr Gadsden, a Mr M’Clenahan of Baltimore, and my Son George. They all but George, returned in the Evening to town. After Sunset I took a Sea Bath at the wharf behind Mrs Black’s house.

23. V:30. My Mother and wife went to Milton to return the visit of the Smith family, and to make enquiries respecting a school at Milton kept by a Mr Pearce, where we think of placing John. Mr B. Smith himself and his Son were here. I received yesterday a Letter from G. A. Otis, soliciting an appointment as Consul at Amsterdam. My brother sent his son Thomas with a Chaise for me to go to his house; but I was detained by visitors until nearly one O’Clock. First Price Greenleaf, Son of Mr T. Greenleaf— He has just arrived from Charleston S. Carolina
where he has resided these two years, and whence he has been obliged to retreat by a malignant fever which is raging there, which is not epidemic, and attacks only Strangers, but among them has been since the beginning of this month frequent, and invariably fatal— The next visitors were Mr and Mrs Daniel Greenleaf and Mrs John Codman, the widow— Then Mr and Mrs T. L. Winthrop, with Mr and Mrs G. Sullivan, and Mr and Mrs Tappan. the Ladies are daughters of Mr Winthrop— Mr Tappan is son of the Doctor Tappan who was professor of divinity at Harvard University.— I went to my brother’s and looked at some of his papers, but we had not time to arrange our accounts. His eldest daughter Elizabeth was ill in bed with a sore throat and fever which prevented his wife from coming to dine at my father’s— He came with me; and immediately after dinner my wife went home with him. George & Charles went with Harriet Welsh to Boston, but came back without her to dinner— Mr and Mrs Whitney, and their daughter Catherine also dined at my father’s. Mr Colman of Hingham came after dinner with Mr May, a young Man who is to take his degree next week. But Mr Norton and Mr Kimball who were to have examined George, did not come. Mr Colman is going next week to Connecticut to be absent ten days, which delays the time of our placing Charles with him. My wife returned about Sunset from my brother’s, and I went with my Mother & her to Mrs: Black’s, where we found Mr R. G. Shaw, Mr Lindsey, Mr Cummins who reminded me of having accidentally met me at the Theatre de la Gaieté at Paris in February 1815—and several Ladies— Mrs Black takes Boarders, and has in the summer Season, many who come out from Boston during the Summer for the benefit of the Country Air. After we came home George came in with his old Schoolmates Claudius Bradford and Thomas Bracket. The close of the Evening was showery.

24. V:30. Attended Meeting. Morning and afternoon. Heard Mr Whitney; whose morning text was from 2. Peter I.5. “Add to your faith virtue; and to virtue knowledge.” That of the afternoon was from Luke XVII:20. “The kingdom of God cometh not by observation,” and the Sermon was against enthusiastic sectaries. There was a cold North-East Storm the whole day, a sudden change from a hot Southwest wind having occurred in the Night. George’s friends Thomas Bracket and Claudius Bradford dined with us. I answered Letters from Mr G. A. Otis and from Messrs John Couper & James Hamilton at Newport Rhode-Island, and called, first at my Uncle Peter B. Adams’s, where I saw his son Boylston Adams, his wife and children.— Then at Thomas Greenleaf’s where I found him with his family sitting round a good fire; and lastly at Captain Beale’s, where I found his son George. He himself was at my father’s where upon my return I met him; and my brother with his wife and Son Thomas. Mr Quincy; young John Marston and his two Sisters. Quincy invited us to dine with him next Thursday week— I received a Letter from John Bailey, applying for the appointment of Chief Clerk in the Department of State, with several others recommending him.

25. V:30. I made a settlement of accounts with my Mother, took up a former note that I had given her, and gave a new one for 1200 dollars, bearing interest from the first of this Month— Went to my brother’s and began the examination of his accounts which we had not time to finish. Captain Hull, with his Lady and her Sister Miss Hart came while I was there; and invited us all to dine with them next Thursday. I returned visits at Mr Marston’s Mr John Greenleaf’s and Mr G. Apthorp’s. He was gone to Boston, but I saw his mother, wife and sister— I paid also another and more solemn visit; to the sepulchre of my father’s Parents— My Mother and wife also spent the morning in paying visits, and several visitors came while I was absent—Mr W. Foster and Charlotte—Mr N. Austin and Master Tilestone and several others. After dinner Mrs Swan, and her daughter the widow of John T. Sargent came. A carriage came out for us from Boston; and in the Evening we came to town— My wife; our three Sons and Lucy.— John and Charles went to Dr Welsh’s— The rest of us lodge at Mrs Jones’s, in Pearl-Street— Mrs S. A. Otis and her daughter Harriet, and Mr James H. Foster with his wife and daughter paid us visits— Many cards of visitors had been left at the house— We received from Mr J. L. Sullivan, an invitation to a party upon the Middlesex Canal, on Thursday which we were obliged to decline.

26: VI: Walking out this morning I met judge Davis who invited me to attend at the new Stone Meeting-house in Summer Street where there was a religious service upon the second anniversary of a theological Institution connected with Harvard University.— I accordingly went, and heard a prayer by President Kirkland, and a Sermon from Amos. II.11— “And I raised up of your Sons for prophets, and of your young men for Nazarites.” by Dr Porter of Roxbury. There was a collection for the benefit of the Institution, which is to assist the education of poor scholars, as Students of divinity. The meeting was very thinly attended. At the Branch Bank I met Mr T. H. Perkins and there were a multitude of visitors calling at our lodgings all the morning. Mr W. Gray was the first, and came with Mr G. Deblois, and a Mr Cleavland, something of an enthusiast.— We received a second invitation from J. L . Sullivan
for a party upon the Canal on Saturday instead of Thursday, which we accepted. I paid a visit, and left a card at the Lieutt. Governor W. Phillips’s. Met my father at the Athenaeum, and went to Dr Welsh’s where my wife and Sons John and Charles dined. My father accompanied me at three O’Clock to the Exchange Coffee-House where the Public Dinner was provided. It was attended by about two hundred persons, the greater part of them my old friends and acquaintance— Mr William Gray presided, and Governor’s Brooks and Phillips, Chief Justice Parker and Judge Story, Generals Dearborn, father and Son, and Humphreys, and Miller, President Kirkland, Dr Freeman, Captain Hull and some others were present as guests. It was near five when we sat down to table, and between eight and nine I retired, with my father, who took my Sons John and Charles with him out to Quincy. I returned to Dr Welsh’s where were Mr and Mrs Hall, Mrs Otis and Harriet—Mr and Mrs Cruft and Mr and Mrs B. L. Pickman. We came home before ten— I asked President Kirkland if he could take my Son George to board in his house. He said he had no room; but that Dr Ware proposed to take two lodgers. I requested him to speak this Evening to Dr Ware, that I may not lose the opportunity. He promised he would. Governor Brooks urgently invited me to dine with him some day before our departure for Washington; but we were already engaged for every day, and I was obliged to decline.

27. VI: Commencement day at Harvard University. I went to Cambridge at nine this Morning and took with me, my Son George and his friend Claudius Bradford. I left them in the College-Yard and went into the Philosophy chamber and Library, where I met many of my friends and acquaintance: among them Mr Rufus King who has come to offer his youngest Son for admission. He had engaged a chamber for him at Professor Ware’s— We went in the procession to the Meeting House, and heard the exercises of the day which were generally very good— Some of them excellent. Among the exercises of the undergraduates the performance of Bancroft, a Son of the Clergyman at Worcester was most distinguished— Both the Orations of the Candidates for the second degree, were above the common Standard. The English in an elegant style, delivered with great animation; the Latin by a South Carolinian named Quash, short, lively, delivered with slow, distinct articulation, and graceful gesture. It was listened to with as close attention, and as warmly applauded as any performance that I ever heard there. We returned with the Procession and dined in the new Stone-Hall, one of the two built since I went from this Country. I had sent back the Carriage for my wife and my brother’s who came from Boston at two O’Clock and dined at Reed’s, with Charles Henry Warren, son of Henry Warren of Plymouth. From thence we went to Porter’s Hall, to Mr Winthrop’s, and then to President Kirkland’s. I called at Dr Ware’s to enquire if he could take my Son to board and lodge at his house. He had only a room on the ground floor, having engaged his only spare chamber this morning to Mr King for his Son. We were apprehensive of the danger to George of sleeping in a room on the ground floor, and concluded to make further enquiry. I went again to President Kirkland’s, where there was a large party at tea. We finally called at Dr Waterhouse’s, and saw him with his family. Young Bourne, son of the late Consul at Amsterdam was there. Dr Waterhouse since I left this Country has lost his wife, and his second son John, who died a few Months since at Charleston, South-Carolina. His youngest Son Benjamin is now there, and graduated this day. My brother returned this Evening to Quincy, intending to come to town and to attend again the performances at Cambridge. His wife came with us to Boston, and we left her at her Sister Mrs P. Foster’s. We got home about 9 O’Clock. George who walked, came an hour later.

28. VI: At nine this Morning I left home, and after paying a visit to General Dearborn, called at the Athenaeum, took up Shaw, and my Son George, and went to Cambridge over what is called Craig’s bridge, finished during my absence.— Shaw alighted at the College-Yard, and I went with George to Dr. Waterhouse’s. I enquired of the Doctor whether he could let George have a chamber and board at his house; but he could not; at least until after the winter vacation— Mr John Appleton and his wife called at the Doctor’s while I was there. I went to President Kirkland’s where I found Mr Isaac Smith, Dr Porter of Roxbury, and Judge Davis— I was anxious to settle arrangements
for George’s board, lodging and instruction. The President went with me first to the new Stone College, or University Hall, where there was a meeting of the Φ.B.K. Society, to call upon Mr Gilman the mathematical tutor, recommended to me by the President as George’s instructor to prepare him for entering as a Sophomore after the next Winter vacation— But Mr Gilman was acting as Secretary at the ΦBK. meeting, and we could not call him out— We went to his Mother’s, where I engaged a chamber, board and lodging for George, and the President promised to speak to Mr Gilman, respecting his terms for instruction, and to give me the notice to-morrow, by a Letter. We attended then the Φ.B.K. performances, which were a prayer by Mr Tappan, an Oration by William Crafts of Charleston S. C. and a Poem by H. Ware—much to the satisfaction of a crowded auditory.— When they had finished, Judge Parker and Mr Quincy, as a Committee from the Φ.B.K. meeting informed me that the Society had this morning chosen me their President.— Judge Parker himself had resigned that office this Morning. I would have declined as being unable to attend to the duties of the Office; but as the general meeting had already adjourned, and another choice could not be made, I finally accepted— Coming out from the Meeting House I met Professor Hedge, much distressed having a child, dying of the dysentery; a disease prevailing greatly at Cambridge. Met and spoke with my old pupil Gallison. I stopped again at President Kirkland’s, but could not see Mr Gilman— I returned to Boston with my wife and Sons. I had sent the Carriage back from Cambridge for her— My brother’s wife was to have accompanied her, but received a message from Quincy this Morning, with information that her daughter Elizabeth has had a relapse of her illness; so that she was obliged to go immediately home— My brother did not come to town— At four I went with my wife and three Sons to the Navy yard, and dined with Captain Hull.— Mrs Hull’s Sisters, Mrs Jarvis and Miss Hart a celebrated Beauty were of the Company, as were Coll. Morris of South Carolina and his Lady, Mr W. Gray, Mr Timothy Bigelow, Speaker of the House of Representatives of this Commonwealth, Mr Lear, Mr G. Sullivan and his wife and others to the number of 23. We spent the Evening at George Sullivan’s with a party of nearly a hundred persons, and came home between eleven and twelve at Night.

29. VI: We had destined this Morning to return as many visits as should be practicable: but excepting a call upon Mr and Mrs Cruft, who are almost our next door neighbours, and which we made immediately after breakfast, we were engaged until close upon two O’Clock with visitors at home. With General Dearborn, Mr Samuel Dana and De Grand, I had conversations which I should have been very desirous of prolonging, but which were interrupted by others. I finally went out and paid visits to Mr Parker the Chief Justice of the Supreme judicial Court of the Commonwealth, and to my old friend Joseph Hall, in Hancock Street. Dined with my wife and George at Mr William Gray’s. My father and mother were there, and a company of 25 persons; among whom was Mrs Scott once Dolly Quincy; then wife of Governor Hancock, and now widow of Captain Scott— Mr William Prescott held some conversation with me concerning the case of the Eastport Revenue Bonds, taken by the British at Moose-Island, and another case at the same period, of which I had not before heard— My father and Louisa Smith returned in the Evening to Quincy. My Mother remained in town. We spent the Evening at Mrs S. A. Otis’s with a family party, and left my Mother at Dr Welsh’s where she passed the Night.

30. VI: At eight this morning we went to Captain Hull’s at the Navy-Yard, and were received with a salute of 13 guns. we went on board the frigates Constitution and Guerriere, lying dismantled at the wharf. Captain Hull accompanied us to the Middlesex Canal, and we went with a party of about seventy persons, in two Boats belonging to the Company to Woburn upon the Canal. Governor Brooks who resides at Medford and Mr P. C. Brooks joined us there. The distance is ten Miles and through a beautiful Country. A collation was provided at Woburn, on the borders of a small Lake, called Horn Pond; and there was a band of music, for the younger part of the party to dance; but we were obliged to return immediately in our Carriage to dine in Boston, at Mr Jonathan Mason’s. George was engaged there with us. John chose also to return with us; but Charles preferred staying with the party, and returned with them in the boat at Night— There was at Mr Mason’s a company of 26 persons, among whom, my father and mother— They returned in the Evening to Quincy, and took our son John with them— George spent the Evening at Mr H. G. Otis’s— We came home about eight O’Clock, much fatigued and immediately closed the day. I have been making enquiries with regard to the school where it will be most expedient to place our two younger Sons, John and Charles— Professor Farrar was of the Canal party this morning. I enquired of him, and found he agreed in opinion with President Kirkland, that the lads offered at the University from the town School in Boston, are in general much better prepared than any others. I have proposed first to place them at Hingham, and afterwards at an Academy at Milton, but my present inclination is to give them the benefit of the town School at Boston.— Mr Farrar told me that the number of Scholars examined yesterday for admission was only 56. little more than half the number that had been expected.

31. V: Employed the morning in the examination of my brother’s accounts, but without getting through with them. After breakfast we left Mrs Jones’s and came out to my father’s house at Quincy. Attended Meeting after dinner and heard Mr White of Dedham, his text was 1. Peter III.15. “And be ready always to give an answer to every man that asketh you a reason of the hope that is in you, with meekness and fear”— The Sermon was good. The delivery not bad— There was an Evening circle at my father’s house. My brother’s wife—Boylston Adams, Captain Beale, Captain T. Bracket, Mr Marston and his two Sons, and Mr De Grand, who told me he wished to have some conversation with me, and will come out again for that purpose, Tuesday Morning.

Day. The Sailor’s life, of our voyage from England, terminated by our landing at New-York on the 6th: instt. since then excepting the short voyage and journey from thence, we have been engaged in a continual round of dissipation by the greetings and kind reception of our friends. I can never be sufficiently grateful to divine Providence for the happy Circumstances which attended my return to my Country; nor can I yet under the painful anticipations of the future abandon the trust upon which I have never relied in vain— But as a first sacrifice this journal must henceforth be given up, or reduced to short and insignificant minutes of the daily occurrences; and my most earnest prayer to God is, that if my powers of usefulness and active industry are taken from me, I may be seasonably sensible of and humbly resigned to my condition, or removed from this earthly scene before the effects of my incapacity have been felt in the Counsels and affairs of my Country.
